definitions: jump into water headfirst with arms extended or hands clasped
move downward quickly and steeply through air or space
engage deeply and enthusiastically in an activity or subject of study
examples: The swimmer dived gracefully from the high platform
Children were diving into the pool all afternoon long
The fighter plane dived steeply toward its target below
Stock prices dived dramatically after the announcement yesterday morning
She dived enthusiastically into her new research project immediately
Students should dive deeper into the historical context first

definitions: move apart or branch off from a common point into different directions
differ or deviate from a standard course opinion or typical pattern
examples: The two roads diverge just beyond the old stone bridge
Their career paths diverged significantly after graduating from college
His opinions diverge sharply from the mainstream political consensus today
The experimental results diverged considerably from our theoretical predictions

definitions: make or become more diverse by adding different elements or types
expand business operations into different products markets or investment areas
examples: The university aims to diversify its student body significantly
Farmers are diversifying their crops to reduce financial risks
The company decided to diversify into renewable energy sectors
Investors should diversify their portfolios across multiple asset classes

definitions: cause something to change course or turn from one direction to another
distract someone's attention from something important or serious to something else
examples: Engineers diverted the river to prevent flooding downstream again
Traffic was diverted through the city center during construction
The comedian diverted attention from the controversial political issue
She tried to divert the conversation away from personal topics

definitions: sell off subsidiary business interests or investments for financial or ethical reasons
deprive or dispossess someone of power rights possessions or clothing
examples: The corporation divested several underperforming subsidiaries last quarter
Universities are divesting from fossil fuel companies increasingly often
The board voted to divest him of his executive powers
Guards divested prisoners of their personal belongings upon arrival

definitions: separate or split something into two or more parts or groups
cause disagreement or hostility between people groups or opinions
calculate how many times one number is contained within another number
examples: She divided the cake into twelve equal pieces carefully
The river divides the city into north and south sections
The controversial issue divided the community into opposing factions
Political rhetoric continues to divide the nation along partisan lines
Students learned to divide large numbers by two digits
Can you divide three hundred by fifteen without a calculator?

definitions: discover or identify something through intuition or supernatural insight rather than evidence
search for underground water or minerals using a divining rod or pendulum
examples: She seemed to divine his thoughts before he spoke them
The fortune teller claimed to divine the future through cards
Local farmers still divine for water using traditional forked sticks
He divined the location of underground pipes with surprising accuracy

definitions: legally dissolve a marriage through formal proceedings in court or law
separate or dissociate something completely from something else that was connected
examples: They decided to divorce after twenty years of marriage
She divorced her husband citing irreconcilable differences last year
You cannot divorce economic policy from social consequences entirely
Modern art divorced itself from traditional representational techniques completely

definitions: make known private or secret information that was previously kept hidden
examples: The witness refused to divulge the source of her information
He finally divulged the company's plans to his closest colleagues
Journalists must protect sources who divulge sensitive government information
She would never divulge personal details about her famous clients

definitions: bring a ship or boat into a dock or harbor for mooring
deduct money from someone's wages or payment as a penalty
connect an electronic device to a docking station or another device
examples: The cruise ship will dock at the port tomorrow morning
Sailors expertly docked the yacht despite the strong winds
The company docked his pay for arriving late repeatedly
They docked her wages to cover the damaged equipment costs
Please dock your laptop to access the external monitors
The spacecraft will dock with the international space station tonight

definitions: place a legal case on the court's calendar for hearing or trial
enter an item or document in an official list or register
examples: The judge docketed the case for next Tuesday morning
Several important appeals were docketed for the fall term
The clerk docketed all incoming correspondence before noon daily
Please docket this invoice in the accounting system immediately

definitions: alter or tamper with something dishonestly to deceive or mislead others
provide medical treatment or care to someone who is ill or injured
examples: Someone doctored the financial reports to hide the losses
They doctored the photograph to remove unwanted background elements
The veterinarian doctored the injured horse throughout the night
She doctored her children's cuts and bruises after playing outside

definitions: record information facts or events in written photographic or other permanent form
provide written evidence or references to support claims statements or research findings
examples: Historians carefully documented the events of the civil war
Scientists must document their experimental procedures thoroughly and accurately
Please document all your sources in the bibliography section
The lawyer documented her case with extensive witness testimonies

definitions: avoid something by moving quickly to one side or changing position suddenly
avoid doing something unpleasant or evade responsibility through clever maneuvering
examples: The boxer dodged his opponent's powerful right hook skillfully
She dodged the ball that came flying toward her head
Politicians often dodge difficult questions during press conferences
He's been dodging his tax obligations for several years now

definitions: follow or pursue someone closely and persistently over time
trouble or plague someone with persistent problems or bad luck
examples: Reporters dogged the celebrity everywhere she went that day
Private investigators dogged his movements for several weeks straight
Financial problems have dogged the company since its founding
Injuries dogged the athlete throughout her professional career unfortunately

definitions: engage in close aerial combat between military fighter aircraft
engage in a fierce struggle or intense competition with an opponent
examples: Fighter pilots dogfought over enemy territory during the mission
The aces dogfought brilliantly in the cloudless sky above
The two companies dogfought for market dominance all year
Political candidates dogfought viciously during the primary election campaign

definitions: have power and control over people situations or territories through strength
be the most prominent important or conspicuous element in a situation
examples: The empire dominated the entire region for three centuries
She dominates every conversation with her loud boisterous personality
Mountains dominate the landscape in this part of the country
Technology companies dominate the stock market indices these days

definitions: put on an item of clothing or equipment especially with deliberate care
examples: The surgeon donned sterile gloves before beginning the operation
Knights would don their armor before riding into battle
Workers must don protective equipment before entering the facility
She donned her finest dress for the diplomatic reception tonight

definitions: give money goods or blood to a charity organization or good cause
contribute something valuable to help a person or advance a cause
examples: She donates regularly to the local food bank organization
Many people donated blood after the natural disaster struck
The billionaire donated millions to establish the new hospital
Alumni often donate funds to support university scholarship programs

definitions: draw patterns or pictures absent-mindedly while thinking about something else
examples: Students often doodle in their notebooks during boring lectures
She doodled flowers and stars while talking on the phone
He doodles constantly during meetings but still pays attention
Children love to doodle with colorful markers on blank paper

definitions: condemn someone or something to certain failure destruction or terrible fate
examples: Poor planning doomed the project from the very beginning
The injury doomed his chances of winning the championship
Rising sea levels may doom coastal cities within this century
Their refusal to adapt doomed the company to bankruptcy eventually

definitions: add drugs to food or drink secretly often to stupefy or harm
work out or figure out a solution to a problem through analysis
examples: Someone doped the racehorse to affect the race outcome
The athlete was caught doping before the Olympic games
Engineers are trying to dope out the technical malfunction
Can you dope out what went wrong with this calculation?

definitions: administer a measured amount of medicine or drug to a person or animal
examples: The nurse dosed the patient with antibiotics every six hours
Parents must carefully dose children's medicine according to weight
Veterinarians dosed the sick cattle with the new vaccine
She dosed herself with painkillers to manage the chronic pain

definitions: mark or decorate something with small round spots or points
be scattered at intervals throughout an area or surface
examples: She dotted the canvas with tiny points of bright paint
Please dot the letter 'i' clearly in your handwriting
Small villages dot the countryside throughout this rural region
Islands dot the ocean surface for hundreds of miles here

definitions: make or become twice as much or as many in size amount or number
serve in two different roles or have two different functions simultaneously
bend or fold something over on itself to create two layers
examples: The company doubled its profits in just three years
Population in the city has doubled since the millennium began
She doubles as both manager and lead designer here
This room doubles as an office during the weekdays
Double the blanket to keep yourself warmer tonight please
He doubled the rope before tying it to the post

definitions: feel uncertain about something or lack confidence in its truth or reliability
question the truth accuracy or genuineness of a statement claim or person
examples: She doubts her ability to complete the marathon successfully
Many investors doubt the economy will recover this year
Scientists doubt the validity of those experimental results strongly
I doubt that he's telling us the complete truth

definitions: fit together perfectly or combine harmoniously with complementary elements or parts
join two pieces of wood using interlocking wedge-shaped projections and recesses
examples: Their skills dovetail perfectly for this collaborative project together
The new evidence dovetails with our existing theory beautifully
The carpenter dovetailed the corners of the wooden drawer
These boards dovetail together without requiring any metal fasteners

definitions: reduce someone or something to a lower grade rank or level of importance
reduce the assessed severity or threat level of something like a storm
examples: The company downgraded him from manager to team leader
Airlines sometimes downgrade passengers when first class is overbooked
Meteorologists downgraded the hurricane to a tropical storm yesterday
Credit agencies downgraded the country's debt rating last month

definitions: copy or transfer data or programs from a remote system to a local device
examples: Students can download course materials from the university website
She downloads movies to watch during her long flights
The software downloads automatically when you click install here
Please download the latest version of the application today

definitions: make something appear less important serious or significant than it really is
examples: Politicians often downplay the severity of economic problems publicly
She downplayed her role in the project's tremendous success
The company tried to downplay the environmental damage reports
Don't downplay your achievements during the job interview tomorrow

definitions: reduce the number of employees in a company to cut costs
move to a smaller home or reduce possessions for simpler living
examples: The corporation downsized by laying off five thousand employees
Many companies downsized during the economic recession last year
They decided to downsize after their children moved away
Retirees often downsize to reduce maintenance and living expenses

definitions: search for underground water or minerals using a divining rod or pendulum
pour water or another liquid over something to extinguish or soak it
examples: Local farmers still dowse for water using forked willow branches
He claimed he could dowse for gold in the mountains
Firefighters dowsed the flames with thousands of gallons of water
She dowsed the campfire thoroughly before leaving the site

definitions: write or compose a preliminary version of a document or text
select someone for compulsory military service or professional sports team
create detailed technical drawings or plans for construction or manufacturing
examples: She drafted the proposal over the weekend for Monday's meeting
Lawyers carefully draft contracts to avoid any legal ambiguities
The army drafted thousands of young men during the war
The team drafted three new players in the first round
Engineers drafted blueprints for the new bridge construction project
Architects draft detailed plans before any building work begins

definitions: pull something along forcefully roughly or with difficulty across a surface
continue for longer than necessary in a boring or tedious way
move an icon or selected text across a computer screen using a mouse
examples: He dragged the heavy suitcase across the airport terminal
The child dragged her teddy bear everywhere she went
The meeting dragged on for three hours without any decisions
Winter seems to drag endlessly in these northern regions
Drag the file icon into the folder to move it
You can drag and drop images directly into the document

definitions: force or pressure someone into doing something against their will through coercion
examples: They dragooned him into joining the committee against his wishes
She was dragooned into organizing the entire charity event alone
The manager dragoons employees into working unpaid overtime regularly
Don't let them dragoon you into something you're uncomfortable doing

definitions: remove liquid from something by letting it flow away through an outlet
gradually deplete or exhaust resources energy or strength from something
flow away gradually through an opening or channel until empty
examples: Please drain the pasta before adding the sauce to it
The surgeon drained fluid from the patient's infected wound
Constant stress drains your energy and affects your health
The project drained the company's financial resources completely
Water slowly drains from the bathtub through the clogged pipe
The color drained from her face when she heard the news

definitions: arrange cloth or fabric in loose graceful folds for decorative effect
cover hang or wrap something loosely with cloth or other material
examples: She draped silk scarves artistically around the window frames
The designer draped fabric over mannequins to test patterns
He draped his jacket casually over the back of the chair
They draped the statue with black cloth for the ceremony

definitions: produce a picture or diagram by making marks on a surface with a pencil or pen
pull something or someone in a particular direction or attract attention interest
extract or obtain something from a particular source container or supply
arrive at a conclusion or inference from evidence or reasoning
examples: Children love to draw pictures of their favorite animals
The architect drew detailed plans for the new building
The magnet draws iron filings toward its surface rapidly
Her speech drew huge crowds to the political rally
Plants draw nutrients from the soil through their roots
She drew water from the well using an old bucket
We can draw several conclusions from this experimental data
The detective drew inferences from the scattered evidence carefully

definitions: anticipate with great fear anxiety or apprehension something that might happen
examples: She dreads speaking in public more than anything else
Students often dread taking their final examinations each semester
He dreaded the thought of losing his job during recession
Many people dread going to the dentist for routine checkups

definitions: experience thoughts images and sensations during sleep in the mind
cherish a hope ambition or aspiration for something in the future
indulge in daydreams or fantasies while awake about pleasant things
examples: She dreams vividly almost every night about strange places
Children often dream about monsters hiding under their beds
He dreams of becoming a professional musician one day
They dreamed about owning their own restaurant for years
Students sometimes dream during boring lectures instead of listening
She was dreaming about her upcoming vacation to Hawaii

definitions: clear the bed of a harbor river or waterway by scooping out mud
bring up or recall something from the past especially unpleasant memories
coat food lightly with flour sugar or another powdered substance before cooking
examples: Workers dredge the harbor channel every spring for ship access
The company dredges rivers to prevent flooding during storms
Journalists dredged up scandals from the politician's past repeatedly
Why must you dredge up those painful memories again now?
Dredge the chicken pieces in seasoned flour before frying them
The chef dredged scallops in breadcrumbs for a crispy coating

definitions: flow or let fall in small drops or a thin stream irregularly
move a ball forward by continuous bouncing in basketball or light kicks in soccer
let saliva run from the mouth involuntarily especially in babies
examples: Water dribbled slowly from the leaky faucet all night
Paint dribbled down the side of the freshly painted wall
The player dribbled expertly through three defenders to score
Children practice dribbling basketballs during their gym class
The baby dribbled milk onto her clean bib again
Some medications cause patients to dribble saliva uncontrollably

definitions: be carried slowly by water or air currents without control or purpose
gradually depart from an intended course plan or previous position
examples: Boats drift downstream when their engines fail in the current
Smoke drifted lazily from chimneys on the calm winter morning
The conversation drifted from politics to personal matters gradually
Students' attention often drifts during long afternoon lectures

definitions: make a hole in something using a drill or similar rotating tool
train someone through repeated practice of an activity or skill
sow seeds in rows by making furrows in prepared soil
examples: Workers drilled holes in the wall for electrical wiring
Dentists drill cavities before filling them with composite material
The coach drills players on basic skills every practice session
Teachers drill students on multiplication tables until memorized
Farmers drill wheat seeds directly into the prepared fields
Modern equipment can drill seeds at precise depths and spacing

definitions: take liquid into the mouth and swallow it for refreshment or nourishment
consume alcoholic beverages especially habitually or to excess
examples: Please drink plenty of water during hot weather conditions
The baby drinks milk from a bottle every three hours
He drinks heavily at parties but never during weekdays
She doesn't drink alcohol for religious and health reasons

definitions: fall in small drops of liquid slowly and steadily from a surface
examples: Water drips constantly from the broken faucet in the bathroom
Paint dripped onto the floor from her wet brush
Blood dripped from the wound until the nurse bandaged it
Condensation drips from air conditioning units during humid weather

definitions: operate and control a motor vehicle to travel from one place to another
compel motivate or force someone to take action or behave in a particular way
propel push or carry something forward with force or momentum
examples: She drives to work every morning despite heavy traffic
Teenagers must pass a test before they can drive legally
Ambition drives her to work incredibly long hours every day
Competition drives companies to innovate and improve their products
Strong winds drove the ship toward the rocky coastline dangerously
The shepherd drives sheep across the meadow toward the barn

definitions: rain lightly in very fine drops that fall slowly and steadily
pour a thin stream of liquid over food in a random pattern
examples: It drizzled throughout the outdoor wedding ceremony unfortunately
The weather forecast says it will drizzle all day tomorrow
The chef drizzled olive oil over the fresh salad greens
Drizzle melted chocolate over the strawberries for decoration

definitions: make a continuous low humming or buzzing sound like an insect
speak at length in a boring monotonous tone without variation
examples: Bees droned lazily around the flowering bushes all afternoon
The air conditioner drones constantly throughout the hot summer
The professor droned on about statistics for two hours straight
Politicians often drone endlessly during campaign speeches

definitions: bend sag or hang downward from weakness tiredness or weight
become dispirited or lose enthusiasm from disappointment or exhaustion
examples: The flowers drooped in the intense afternoon heat yesterday
His eyelids drooped heavily after working all night long
Her spirits drooped when she heard the disappointing news
The team's morale drooped after losing five games consecutively
